item.title: Patrick Betters Shares His Battle with Cancer
item.description:
Patrick Betters Shares His Battle with Cancer

My name is Patrick Betters and I am a 6 year cancer survivor. In 2006 I was a senior in high school, ready to live up to all of my expectations of my last high school wrestling season.

item.title: Patrick Betters | A St. Baldrick's Honored Kid
item.description:
Patrick Betters | A St. Baldrick's Honored Kid

Thank you for supporting me and the more than 300,000 kids worldwide who will be diagnosed with cancer this year. By sharing the gifts of your time, talent and money with the St. Baldrick's Foundation, you're supporting research to give all kids with cancer a better chance for a cure.

item.title: No Splitting Hairs: Chaparral wrestler battles cancer with sturdy support from his teammates
item.description:
No Splitting Hairs: Chaparral wrestler battles cancer with sturdy support from his teammates

TEMECULA - Thirty-five shaved heads enter Chaparral's wrestling room for practice every afternoon. Thirty-four are close to being hairless by choice. One is out of necessity. Sept. 18, 2006 will be a day Maria Betters and Jacob Heisinger will never forget. It was early that morning - about 1 a.m.

item.title: Play: Speaking For Radys Childrens Hospital - Childhood Cancer Story
item.description:
Play: Speaking For Radys Childrens Hospital - Childhood Cancer Story

Speaking For Radys Childrens Hospital - Childhood Cancer Story

item.title: Patrick Betters, Non-Hodgkin T-Cell Lymphoma
item.description:
Patrick Betters, Non-Hodgkin T-Cell Lymphoma

Patrick was a normal 17 year-old high school senior when he was diagnosed with stage 3 Non-Hodgkin t-cell lymphoma in September, 2006. After two months of treatment, Patrick's immune system was depleted and he developed a fungal infection that is usually fatal.

item.title: No title
Captain America surprises local teen fighting cancer
item.description:
Captain America surprises local teen fighting cancer

EL CAJON, Calif. -- A high school student battling cancer received an empowering message Friday from one of the biggest movie superheroes in Hollywood. Captain America has been inspiring 18-year-old Ryan Wilcox during his long battle with cancer, and Ryan's dream has been to meet Chris Evans, the actor who plays his hero.

item.title: 'The Closer You Get to Death, the More You Want to Live' - Inspiring College Student with Incurable Cancer Raised Millions for Research
item.description:
'The Closer You Get to Death, the More You Want to Live' - Inspiring College Student with Incurable Cancer Raised Millions for Research

At 13, James Ragan was an affable, lanky, top-ranked junior tennis player in Texas, competing in Europe for the summer and dreaming of life as a pro. A sudden swelling in his left knee caused concern, but James never imagined what would soon unfold.
